results.title: Hester Ford, Oldest American, Dies
results.abstract: She was believed to be either 115 or 116. She experienced two pandemics and two world wars and lived under 21 presidents.

multimedia.caption: Hester Ford in 2016 celebrating her 111th birthday. “She was a reminder of how far we have come as people on this earth,” her great-granddaughter said.
multimedia.copyright: Diedra Laird/The Charlotte Observer, via Associated Press

results.title: A private school in Miami, citing false claims, bars vaccinated teachers from contact with students.
results.abstract: Centner Academy advertises its support for “medical freedom from mandated vaccines,” and has recently hosted talks by antivaccine advocates.

multimedia.caption: Centner Academy in Miami sent teachers a letter repeating false claims that being vaccinated made people a health risk. People waited to receive a shot at Miami Dade College.

results.title: Airline Bars Alaska State Senator Over Mask Policy Violation
results.abstract: Alaska Airlines said it had suspended State Senator Lora Reinbold from flying because she refused to comply with its mask rules.

results.title: Amid Second Virus Wave, the World Responds to India’s Distress Call
results.abstract: Countries, companies and powerful members of the diaspora have all pledged to pitch in, but it likely won’t be enough to stop the unfolding catastrophe.

results.title: A Look at Covid-19 Vaccine ‘Passports,’ Passes and Apps Around the Globe
results.abstract: A variety of digital and old-fashioned approaches are being used  to confirm  vaccination for entry to public places. But the world is still far from a universal standard of proof for crossing borders.

multimedia.caption: The Dutch app, which is currently in development, will never show a bouncer why a person produced a large green tick mark or a red “bar code cannot be read” to try to minimize awkwardness.

results.title: Crohn’s Disease Is on the Rise
results.abstract: Many think the abdominal disorder starts in childhood, but it can occur at any age and is becoming more prevalent throughout the world.

results.title: 5 Takeaways From the New Food Allergy Law
results.abstract: Sesame becomes a “major allergen,” joining milk, eggs, fish, shellfish, tree nuts, peanuts, wheat and soybeans.

results.title: Fauci and other top U.S. health officials stress the urgency of vaccinations and their safety.
results.abstract: Now that the J&J pause has lifted, the government is pushing to get most adult Americans inoculated this summer.

results.title: $1 Million in Toxic Bleach Sold as ‘Miracle’ Cure, Officials Say
results.abstract: A Florida grand jury indicted a man and his three sons, accusing them of marketing an “unproven and potentially harmful” solution as a remedy for Covid-19, cancer, autism and more.
org_facet: Genesis II Church of Health and Healing

results.title: Millions Are Skipping Their Second Doses of Covid Vaccines
results.abstract: Nearly 8 percent of those who got initial Pfizer or Moderna shots missed their second doses. State officials want to prevent the numbers from rising.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

results.title: Look How Far Weave Come
results.abstract: On the first anniversary of the At Home section, zigzag through this puzzle to reveal the twist.
results.byline: By Andrew Dore and Robert Vinluan

results.title: Teach Your Kids to Resist Hatred Toward Asians
results.abstract: Books make great educational resources to combat discrimination and xenophobia, and to foster activism.

results.title: How to Get Back Into the Job Market
results.abstract: Many job seekers don’t know where to look after the year we’ve just had. If you count yourself among this crowd, here’s how to get back into the market, even if you’re feeling rusty.

results.title: Explore Coral Reefs and Enjoy Flower Arrangements Inspired by Art
results.abstract: This week, watch a puppetry performance, break your Ramadan fast with a virtual open mic and iftar or listen to music from Yosmel Montejo and Vox Sambou.
results.byline: By Emma Grillo and Danya Issawi

results.title: J.&.J. Vaccine Will Be Available Again Soon
results.abstract: U.S. experts weigh the risks for younger women and cases of a rare blood-clotting disorder, and lift the pause in giving the one-shot vaccine.
results.byline: By Denise Grady, Julie Bosman and Noah Weiland
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

results.title: Nick Springer, Paralympic Gold Medalist, Dies at 35
results.abstract: A quadruple amputee, he was a relentless defender on the United States’ wheelchair rugby team, which won a gold medal at the 2008 Paralympics in Beijing.

multimedia.caption: Nick Springer in 2012 during the Paralympics in London. He took up wheelchair rugby in 2003, telling his father, “‘Dad, I think I can be really good at this.’”
Nick Springer in 2012 during the Paralympics in London. He took up wheelchair rugby in 2003, telling his father, “‘Dad, I think I can be really good at this.’”

results.title: Many Covid patients have new ailments months after recovering from mild cases, a C.D.C. study finds.
results.abstract: Two-thirds of those in the study sought medical care a month to six months afterward, and about two-thirds of those who sought care were found to have an entirely new medical condition.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: A mobile Covid-19 walk-up testing site in Los Angeles. A new study says that many adults who have mild cases of Covid-19 can, months later, receive diagnoses of new ailments.
multimedia.copyright: Philip Cheung for The New York Times

results.title: Are You Struggling With Feelings of Guilt?
results.abstract: Tell us how the pandemic has contributed to the guilt that you are experiencing. You may be contacted by a reporter for inclusion in an upcoming article.

results.title: A new study hints at a reason the J.&J. and AstraZeneca vaccines may cause blood clots in rare cases.
results.abstract: A panel of experts advising the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is discussing rare blood clots that health officials have investigated in Johnson & Johnson coronavirus vaccine recipients.

results.title: Battle of the Seas: Cruise Lines vs. the C.D.C.
results.abstract: Cruise companies and their allies are fighting against rules that have kept U.S. ships from sailing. But experts say controlling the coronavirus onboard is a complex puzzle.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

multimedia.caption: Royal Caribbean’s Navigator of the Seas docked at PortMiami in Florida. The company has scheduled sailings out of Bermuda and the Bahamas, while departures from United States ports are stalled.

results.title: Thomas Brock, Whose Discovery Paved the Way for PCR Tests, Dies at 94
results.abstract: In 1966, he found heat-resistant bacteria in a hot spring at Yellowstone National Park. That led to the development of the chemical process behind the coronavirus test.

multimedia.caption: Thomas Brock in 1992 at a hot spring in Yellowstone National Park. It was there, 26 years earlier, that he found Thermus aquaticus, a species of bacteria that would be used to develop the chemical process behind PCR testing for the coronavirus.

Thomas Brock in 1992 at a hot spring in Yellowstone National Park. It was there, 26 years earlier, that he found Thermus aquaticus, a species of bacteria that would be used to develop the chemical process behind PCR testing for the coronavirus.

results.abstract: How to cope with a less cautious world as pandemic restrictions loosen.
